text:
SHAPE

AREAS AND VOLUMES OF PLANE SHAPES

Plane Mensuration

A plane shape is any shape that is drawn on a paper or wall. It is a 2D figure without depth. Circle, rectangle, triangle etc are all plane 2D shapes. A plane shape has an outline and therefore, encloses an area. This is called the area of the plane shape. 

The area of a plane shape is defined as the product of the length, l and the side length (breadth), b ie A[EMMANUEL 1] = l × b. Notice the use of the word "defined". There is nothing inherent about the area of a plane shape that it should go by l × b. We only chose this definition for the area and work with it. 

Below is a list of common plane shapes and their areas. We will be working with these formulae for calculations concerning areas of plane shapes.

 

                            

  Plane Shape

                          Area of Plane Shape

l, w, b, h are the length, width (side length), base (length)  and height respectively.

Rectangle

l × w

Square

l × l = l2

Triangle

1/2 bh

Trapezium

1/2 (a+b)h  a, b are the lengths of the opposite sides

Circle

πr2

Parallelogram

b × h

Rhombus 

b × h

 

Solid Mensuration

Unlike plane shapes which have no depth, solid shapes are 3D shapes with a length, side and depth. They are real life shapes that you can touch and feel eg a cup, baseball, bucket etc are all solid 3D shapes. Solid shapes have volume and NOT area. While plane shapes enclose an area/surface, solid shapes rather take up actual space/volume. 

The volume of a uniform solid shape is defined as V = A × h where A represents the uniform cross-section/base of the solid shape and h is the depth. We emphasize again that this is just a convention that was adopted. There is no inherent reason why the volume of a solid shape should be A × h. We only work with this as a standard for measuring volume, but that's all. 

Below is a comparison of plane and solid shapes and their volumes.

 

Plane Shape

Solid Shape

Volume of Solid Shape

Rectangle

Cuboid

l × w × h

Square

Cube

l × w × h = l3 since l=w=h

Circle

___

___

A × h     A is the base area of the uniform prism.

___

πr2h

___

Pyramid

Q1: A trapezium has two parallel sides of length 6cm and 8cm. If the area of the trapezium is 42cm2, find the distance between the parallel sides.

Solution

A=42cm2, a=6cm, b=8cm, h=?

A = 1/2 (a+b)h  => h=2A/(a+b)

h = (2×42)/(6+8) = 84/14

:. h = 6cm

 

Q2: A pyramid 12cm high stands on a rectangular base of length 7cm and width 5cm. Calculate the volume of the pyramid.

Solution

Given l=7cm, w=5cm and h=12cm.

The base of the pyramid a rectangle. Therefore, the base area, A of the pyramid is given by A=l×w

=> A=7×5=35cm2

V=1/3 Ah = 1/3 × 35 × 12 = 35 × 4

:. V = 140cm3

 

Q3: What is the volume of a cone with base diameter of 6cm and height 5cm? [Leave your answer in terms of π]

Solution

d=6cm => r = d/2 = 6/2 = 3cm, h = 5cm

V = 1/3 πr2h => V=1/3 × π × 32× 5

:. V = 15π cm3

 

Q4: How many 30cm square tiles would be enough to cover a 7.2m by 4.2m rectangular floor?

Solution

The area of a square tile is 30×30=900cm2

The floor measures 7.2m (7.2×100=720cm) by 4.2m (4.2×100=420cm)

:. The floor spans 720×420=302,400cm2

The question could then be rephrased thus: "how many 900cm2

tiles would be required to cover a 302,400cm2 rectangular floor?"

If the number be x,

900x=302,400

:. x = 336 square tiles

Notice how we converted the dimensions of the floor to cm. The units have to be unity. If we wanted, we could have converted cm to m and work in m. Either way, we will still arrive at the same answer.

 

Q5: What is the volume of a metal box 5cm × 3cm × 4cm?

Solution

V=lwh = 5×3×4

:. V = 60cm3

 

Q6: How many 3cm sugar cubes will fit perfectly in a carton measuring 5cm×3cm×1cm?

Solution

Each cube takes up a volume of 33=27cm3

The carton itself has a volume of 5×3×1=15cm3

If the number of sugar cubes be x,

27x=15

:. x=15/27= 5/9 sugar cubes

Can you interprete this result? I mean it's not 1 cube or 5 cubes but 5/9 cubes. What?

Well, it means that not even a single cube can contain inside the carton. The reason is quite obvious from the measurements given above. Instead, take a cube and divide it into 9 equal parts. Only 5 parts out of the 9 will fit inside the carton.

 

Q7: A right angle triangular prism has base 7cm and height 2cm. If the length of the prism is 5cm, what is the volume material of the prism?

Solution

Base area, A= 1/2 × 7 × 2 = 7cm2, h=5cm

V=1/3 Ah = 1/3 × 7 × 5 

:. V = 11.67cm3

PUME Example

The ratio of the sides of two similar rectangular blocks is 5:3. If the volume of smaller block is 324 cm3, that of the other block is

A. 1500 cm3, B. 900 cm3, C. 864 cm3, D. 540 cm3

 

A (2017/2018, no 2)

Volume = l  b  h (i.e. L3)

Volume varies directly as a cube of the sides.

Volume of the larger block = 324 = 1,500

 

Example

Two triangles have the same area if 

A. The three angles of one are equal to the three angles of the other, B. if the three sides of one are equal to the three sides of the other, C. they lie between the same parallels, D. they are similar

 

B. (2015/2015, no 10)

Two triangles have the same area, if the three sides of one are equal to the three sides of the other. The three sides being equal means that they also have equal three angles. Note that two triangles can have equal angles but different length in sides and therefore have different area.

Two triangles are said to be congruent when they are equal in all respect (their area, 3 sides and 3 internal angles).

 

Example

If two triangles are similar, then 

I. the corresponding angles are equal 

II. the corresponding sides are proportional 

III. the areas of the triangles are in the same ratio as the lengths of the corresponding sides 

IV. the triangles are congruent 

Which of the above statements are CORRECT?

A. I and II only, B. Ill and IV only, C. I, II and III only, D. I, III and IV only 

A (2017/2018, no 8)

I. the corresponding angles are equal 

II. the corresponding sides are proportional 

Two triangles are said to be congruent when they are equal in all respect (their area, 3 sides and 3 internal angles).

 

Example

A regular polygon with (2m + 1) sides has each interior angle equal to 144°. The value of m is 

A. 4, B. 5, C. 8, D. 10

 

A (2015/2016, no 2).

The formular for the sum of the interior angle of a regular polygon is given by

= (2n – 4)  90

n = number of sides

if each angle is x the total angle will be = x  n

(2n – 4)  90 = x  n

given that n = (2m + 1), and each angle = 144°

= (2(2m + 1) – 4)  90 = 144°  (2m + 1)

= (4m - 2) 90= 144° (2m + 1)

Divide both sides by 90

(4m - 2) = 1.6(2m + 1)

4m – 2 = 3.2m + 1.6

4m – 3.2m = 1.6 + 2

0.8m = 3.6

m = 4.5

m = 4

 

Example

If the mass of a solid metal sphere of radius 3 cm is 9 kg, the mass of a spherical shell of the same metal whose internal and external radii are 2 cm and 3 cm respectively is 

A. 4 1/2 kg, B. 6 kg, C. 6 1/3 kg, D. 7 1/2 kg

C (2015/2016, no 4).

 

This is solved by comperism

Volume of sphere = r3

Volume of solid sphere = (3)3 = 36 cm3

Volume of solid sphere = (33 - 22) 

= (9 4) =  cm3

 Recall, the mass of a solid metal sphere of radius 3 cm is 9 kg, comparing them we have,

36 cm3  9

  x cm3 

36 x =   9

36 x =   3

x =  = 6

x = 6 cm3

Example

A chord of a circle of radius 13cm is drawn 5cm from the centre of the circle. Find the length of the chord.

A. 12cm, B. 24cm, C. 18cm, D. √194 cm 

B (2007/2008, no 5).

According to the diagram the chord length = x + x = 2x

We can solve for x using Pythagoras theory

A2 + B2 = C2

52 + x2 = 132

25 + x2 = 169

x2 = 169 – 25 = 144

x =  = 12

chord length = x + x = 2x

= 2 x 12 = 24cm

 

Example

In the diagram below, O is the centre of the circle of radius 42cm. Find the area of the shaded Portion (Take = 22/7).

 

A. 903 cm2, B. 441 cm2, C. 462 cm2, D. 21 cm2

 

D (2008/2009, no 8)

The shaded portion is a segment 

The Area of a segment = Area of a sector – Area of the inscribed triangle

Area of a sector = 

=  = 462

Area of a sector = 462

Area of the inscribed triangle = 

=    = 

Area of the inscribed triangle = 441

The Area of a segment = Area of a sector – Area of the inscribed triangle

= 462 – 441= 21cm2

 

Circle theorems

Circle Theorem 1: Angles at the centre and at the circumference

The angle at the centre is twice the angle at the circumference. (Note that both angles are facing the same piece of arc, CB).

 

Circle Theorem 2: Angle in a semicircle.

 

The angle in a semi-cicle is 90°.(This is a special case of theorem 1, with a centre angle of 180°.)

 

Circle Theorem 3: Angles in the same segment

Angles in the same segment are equal. (The two angles are both in the major segment;

I've coloured the minor segment grey).

 

Circle Theorem 4: Angles in a cyclic quadlateral

Opposite angles in a cyclic quadrilateral add up to 180°. [A cyclic quadrilateral has all 4 vertices (corners) touching a circle]

Circle Theorem 5: Length of tangents

The lengths of the two tangents from a point to a circle are equal. CD = CE.

 

Circle Theorem 6: Angle between circle tangent and radius

 

The angle between a tangent (eg DC) and a radius (eg AD) in a circle is 90°.

Circle Theorem 7: Alternate segment theorem

The angle (α) between the tangent (DC) and the chord (DF) at the point of contact (D) is equal to the angle (β) in the alternate segment*. ie α = β

[This is a weird theorem, and needs a bit more explanation: Chord DF splits the circle into two segments. In one segment, there is an angle, β, 'facing' the chord, DF – this segment is called the alternate segment. Partly in the other segment, and partly outside the circle altogether, the angle α, is between the chord DF and the tangent DC]

 

Circle Theorem 8: Perpendicular from the centre bisects the chord

The perpendicular from centre A cuts the chord CD at E, the centre point of the chord, so that

DE = EC

 

EQUATION

Equation is a statement that two things are equal. 

Brackets in equation

Brackets should be simplified before other procedures are to be taken in any expression or equation. 

e.g. x = 12 – (11 – 4x) 

x = 12 – 11 + 4x

collect like terms

x + 4x = 12 – 11

5x = 1

x = 1/5

 

Equations with fraction

Always clear fractions before solving an equation. To clear fraction, multiply each term in the equation by the L.C.M of the denominator of the fraction.

e.g.  = 5

multiply both side by 2 to remove the fraction.

  2 = 5  2

x – 7 = 10

x = 10 + 7

x = 17

 

Solving quadratic equation by factorization

E.g.

Factorize the quadratic expression

x2 – 4x – 12

Procedure

x2 – 4x – 12 = (    ) (    ).

1st step fill x in each of the brackets

(x    )(x    )

2nd step, list out all the factors of -12

-12 and 1, 12 and 1, -4 and 3, 4 and -3, -6 and 2, 6 and -2.

 

3rd Step, find the factors, whose sum is the coefficient (-4)

It is only -6 and 2

 

4th step, insert the numbers separately in the bracket

(x – 6)(x + 2) Ans

Methods of Solving a System of Equations in Two Variables

A value of each of the unknown or variable satisfies both the equation simultaneously. These values of the variables are the roots of the equations.

A. Elimination Method

In this method, we eliminate one of the variables (say x) from the equation. In other words, two linear equations are reduced to form only one linear equation by eliminating one of the unknowns. Suppose we have,

x = 16 – y… (eq1)

and, x = 4 + y … (eq2)

Since the L.H.S. of both the equations is same, we equate both equations.

We have, 16 – y = 4 + y 

Collect like terms

16 - 4 = y + y 

12 = 2y

y = 6 

and now we can substitute the value of y to solve for x with any of the equation.

solving for x, 

let’s use eq1

x = 16 – y

x = 16 – 6 = 10

x = 10

 

B. Cross Multiplication Method

In this method we cross multiply the equations with respective coefficients. Subtracting the two equations thus formed gives the required answer. If the two equations are

a1 x + b1 y + c1 = 0, and

a2 x + b2 y + c2 = 0, 

Assume we have,

x + y = 16 … (i)

x – y = 4 … (ii)

Multiplying (i) by (−1) and (ii) by (1), 

-x - y = -16

-x + y = -4

and then subtracting the new equations we have,

−x – x – y + y = −16 – 4

= −2x = −20

x = 10

we can then substitute and solve for y to get 6.

Example

Find the equation of the line which passes through (-2, 1) and is perpendicular to the 

line 4x-2y+1=0 

A. 2y – x - 4= 0, B. 2y+x =0, C. 2y—x= 0, D. y — 2x-5 =0 

B (2005/2006 no 9).

 

The equation for the given line is 

4x-2y+1=0

Converting to a proper form

-2y = -4x -1

Dividing by -2

y = 2x + ½ 

let’s call the gradient of the perpendicular line m2

recall m1 x m2 = -1 (for perpendicular lines).

 

m2 = - ½ through (-2, 1)

the equation can be written as 

y – 1 = - ½ [X – (-2)] 

y – 1 = - ½ (X +2) 

2y + x = 0

Observe the options to know where you will stop.

Example

If a line is parallel to the line 2y - rx +4 = 0 and perpendicular to the line 4y+ x —28 = 0 then the value of r is 

A. 4, B. 8, C. -8, D. -4 

B (2005/2006, no 10)

recall m1 x m2 = -1 (for perpendicular lines).

Convert the equations to a proper form

First line = 2y - rx +4 = 0

2y = rx – 4

Divide by 2

y = x – 2

2nd line = 4y+ x —28 = 0

4y = - x + 28

Divide by 4

y =   + 7

y = x + 7

recall that the gradient is the coefficient of x; y = mx + c

gradient = m in the expression

comparing the equation

gradient of 1st line =

 = -1

 

r = -8
